title: Authors and Citation
text: Blas Benito. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Benito B (2023). collinear: Automated Multicollinearity Management. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://blasbenito.github.io/collinear/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {collinear: Automated Multicollinearity Management},   author = {Blas Benito},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://blasbenito.github.io/collinear/}, }

title: Automated Multicollinearity Management
text: R package reduce multicollinearity training data frames.

title: collinear: Automated Multicollinearity Management — collinear-package
text: package (one paragraph).

title: collinear: Automated Multicollinearity Management — collinear-package
text: Maintainer: Blas Benito blasbenito@gmail.com (ORCID)

title: Pairwise correlation — cor_df
text: Returns pairwise Pearson correlation pairs predictors training dataset. Please note near-zero variance columns ignored function. Use mc_auto_vif() remove .

title: Pairwise correlation — cor_df
code: cor_df(df = NULL, predictors = NULL, method = NULL)

title: Pairwise correlation — cor_df
text: df (required; data frame tibble) data frame predictors. Default: NULL. predictors (optional; character vector) Character vector names predictive variables. Every element vector must column names df. Default: NULL method (optional; charater string) Method used compute pairwise correlations. Accepted methods "pearson" (recommended minimum 30 rows 'df') "spearman" (recommended minimum 10 rows 'df'). Default: "pearson".

title: Pairwise correlation — cor_df
text: Data frame pairs predictors correlation.

title: Pairwise correlation — cor_df
code: if(interactive()){  data(   ecoregions,   ecoregions_predictors )  df <- cor_df(       df = ecoregions,       predictors = ecoregions_predictors )  }

title: Correlation matrix — cor_matrix
text: Returns correlation matrix pairs predictors training dataset. Non-numeric predictors transformed numeric via target encoding.

title: Correlation matrix — cor_matrix
code: cor_matrix(df = NULL, method = NULL)

title: Correlation matrix — cor_matrix
text: df (required; data frame tibble) data frame predictors. Default: NULL. method (optional; charater string) Method used compute pairwise correlations. Accepted methods "pearson" (recommended minimum 30 rows 'df') "spearman" (recommended minimum 10 rows 'df'). Default: "pearson".

title: Correlation matrix — cor_matrix
text: Data frame pairs predictors correlation.

title: Correlation matrix — cor_matrix
code: if(interactive()){  data(   ecoregions,   ecoregions_predictors )  df <- cor_df(       df = ecoregions,       predictors = ecoregions_predictors )  }

what: Plant richness and predictors of American ecoregions — ecoregions
title: Plant richness and predictors of American ecoregions — ecoregions
text: Richness vascular plants American ecoregions defined Ecoregions 2017, computed GBIF data, environmental predictors.

title: Plant richness and predictors of American ecoregions — ecoregions
code: data(ecoregions)

title: Plant richness and predictors of American ecoregions — ecoregions
text: data frame 225 rows 49 columns: ecoregion_id: Numeric id ecoregion. ecoregion_name: Name ecoregion according Ecoregions 2017. x y: Numeric, coordinates ecoregion centroids, EPSG 4326. plant_richness: Number vascular species found ecoregion. Response variable. plant_richness_binary: Binary version plant_richness, value 1 plant_richness higher 5000, 0 otherwise. ecoregion_area_km2: Area ecoregion squared kilometers. sampling_bias: Indicator sampling bias, measured number vascular plant species found ecoregion divided number GBIF records ecoregion, divided area ecoregion. neighbors_count, neighbors_area, neighbors_percent_shared_edge, neighbors_average_aridity: Number, area sum, proportion shared edge, average aridity direct neighbors ecoregion. climate_aridity_index_average: Average aridity index ecoregion. climate_bio1_average climate_bio15_average: Bioclimatic variables representing average annual temperature (BIO1), temperature_seasonality (BIO4), average maximum temperature warmest month (BIO5), minimum, average maximum monthly rainfall (BIO12), precipitation seasonlality (BIO15). climate_hypervolume: Volume climatic envelope ecoregion, computed hypervolume package. landcover_bare_percent_average, landcover_herbs_percent_average, landcover_trees_percent_average, landcover_ndvi_average: Average cover percentage bare soil, herbs, trees, NDVI, extracted MODIS Vegetation Continuous Fields MODIS NDVI/EVI product. topography_elevation_average topography_elevation_range: Average elevation ecoregion range. fragmentation_ai fragmentation_te: Geographic fragmentation indices ecoregion,  computed R package landscapemetrics. primary_productivity: Character. Ordered character version column landcover_ndvi_average. landlocked: Binary. Defines whether ecoregion landlocked (value 1) (value 0). dominant_landcover: Factor. Dominant landcover ecoregion (one : "bare", "herbs", "trees"), computed columns landcover_bare_percent_average, landcover_herbs_percent_average, landcover_trees_percent_average.

what: Names of all predictor variables — ecoregions_predictors
title: Names of all predictor variables — ecoregions_predictors
text: Character vector names predictors.

title: Names of all predictor variables — ecoregions_predictors
code: data(ecoregions_predictors)

title: Names of all predictor variables — ecoregions_predictors
text: Character vector 43 predictor names.

what: Target encoding of character and factor variables — fe_target_encoding
title: Target encoding of character and factor variables — fe_target_encoding
text: Target encoding involves replacing values categorical variables continuous values indicative response variable. several approaches target encoding, including calculating mean target value level categorical variable. Target encoding can useful improving performance machine learning models, can also introduce bias encoded values representative true underlying relationship categorical variables target. function identifies categorical variables input data frame, transforms using set methods defined user, returns input data frame newly encoded variables. target encoding methods implemented function : rank: returns order group integer, 1 rank group lower mean response variable. method accepts  noise argument, adds white noise result increase data variability reduce leakage. variables returned method named suffix "__encoded_rank". method implemented function fe_target_encoding_rank(). mean: uses mean value response group categorical variable. option accepts noise. variables returned method named suffix "__encoded_mean".  method implemented function fe_target_encoding_mean(). rnorm: method computes mean standard deviation response group categorical variable, uses rnorm() generate values taken normal distribution. argument sd.width used multiplier standard deviation reduce range values produced rnorm() group categorical predictor. variables returned method named suffix "__encoded_rnorm".  method implemented function fe_target_encoding_rnorm(). loo: leave-one-method. categorical value replaced mean response variable across cases within group. variables returned method named suffix "__encoded_loo". method implemented function fe_target_encoding_loo(). methods "mean" "rank" support noise argument. Values larger zero argument add white noise target-encoded variables using stats::rnorm() via function fe_target_encoding_noise()). noise argument represents fraction average differences groups target-encoded variable. example, noise = 0.25 target-encoded variable unique values c(1, 2, 3), case using "rank" method, average -groups difference 1, range noise added row go 0 0.25 method "rnorm" argument sd.width, multiplies standard deviation argument rnorm() function limit spread encoded values groups.

title: Target encoding of character and factor variables — fe_target_encoding
code: fe_target_encoding(   df = NULL,   response = NULL,   predictors = NULL,   methods = c("mean", "rank", "loo", "rnorm"),   sd.width = 0.1,   seed = 1,   noise = 0,   replace = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Target encoding of character and factor variables — fe_target_encoding
text: df (required; data frame, tibble, sf) training data frame. Default: NULL response (required; character string) Name response. Must column name df. Default: NULL predictors (required; character vector) Names predictors df. character factor predictors processed, returned "df" slot function's output.  Default: NULL methods (optional; character string). Name target encoding methods. Default: c("mean", "rank", "loo", "rnorm") sd.width (optional; numeric vector) method "rnorm". Numeric vector multiplicators standard deviation group categorical variable, range 0.01-1. Default: 0.1 seed (optional; integer) Random seed facilitate reproducibility. Default: 1 noise (optional; numeric vector) methods "mean" "rank". Numeric vector noise values range 0-1. Default: 0. replace (optional; logical) Advanced option changes behavior function. Use really know exactly need. TRUE, first option methods, noise, sd.width arguments used, replaces categorical variable encoded version, returns input data frame encoded variables without original ones. Default: FALSE verbose (optional; logical) TRUE, messages plots generated execution function displayed. Default: TRUE

title: Target encoding of character and factor variables — fe_target_encoding
text: target encoding needed predictors numeric, function returns df. Otherwise returns list class "fe_target_encoding" slots: data: Input data frame, target-encoded character factor columns. leakage_test: Data frame results linear model target-encoded variable response aimed identify potential data leakage. contains following columns: encoded_predictor: name target-encoded variable. correlation_with_response: R-squared resulting cor.test() target-encoded variable response. interpretation: Interpretation test, values "Leakage", "Likely leakage", "Unlikely leakage", "leakage". find concerning results, may either increase value noise argument (method = "mean"), select "rnorm" method. advanced option replace TRUE, input data frame returned categorical variables replaced encoded versions.

title: Target encoding of character and factor variables — fe_target_encoding
code: if(interactive()){  #loading example data data(   ecoregions,   ecoregions_continuous_response,   ecoregions_all_predictors   )  #the dataframe ecoregions contains two categorical variables unique(ecoregions$dominant_landcover) unique(ecoregions$primary_productivity)  #applying all methods for a continuous response output <- fe_target_encoding(   data = ecoregions,   response = ecoregions_continuous_response,   predictors = ecoregions_all_predictors,   methods = c(     "mean",     "rank",     "rnorm",     "loo"   ),   sd.width = c(0.01, 0.1, 1),   noise = c(0, 1) )  #the output has several objects names(output)  #names of the encoded predictors output$encoded_predictors  #the data with the original and the encoded predictors colnames(output$data)  #a leakage test assessing the correlation between the response and the encoded predictors output$leakage_test  #plotting the transformations of "primary_productivity" tidyr::pivot_longer(   data = output$data,   cols = dplyr::all_of(     grep(       pattern = "primary_productivity",       x = output$encoded_predictors,       value = TRUE)     ) ) |>   dplyr::select(     plant_richness,     primary_productivity,     name,     value   ) |>   ggplot2::ggplot() +   ggplot2::aes(     x = plant_richness,     y = value,     color = primary_productivity   ) +   ggplot2::facet_wrap(~name, scales = "free_y") +   ggplot2::geom_point() +   ggplot2::labs(     x = "Response values",     y = "Encoded values",     color = "Original\ngroups"   )  }

title: Autommated multicollinearity reduction — mc_auto
text: Reduces multicollinearity set predictors sequentially applying mc_auto_cor() mc_auto_vif(). function mc_auto_cor() applies recursive algorithm remove variables Pearson correlation another variable higher given threshold (defined argument max.cor).  two variables correlated threshold, one highest sum R-squared variables removed. function mc_auto_vif() applyies Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) analysis reduce multicollinearity. VIF given variable y computed 1/(1-R2), R2 multiple R-squared multiple regression model fitted using y response remaining variables input data set predictors. equation can interpreted "rate perfect model's R-squared unexplained variance model". possible range VIF values (1, Inf]. VIF lower 10 suggest removing y data set reduce overall multicollinearity. recommended thresholds maximum VIF may vary depending source consulted, common values, 2.5, 5, 10. argument preference.order allows user "protect" variables might interesting even required given analysis. preference.order provided, predictors ranked lower higher sum R-squared preodictors, removed one one maximum R-squared correlation matrix lower max.cor maximum VIF max.vif. Please note near-zero variance columns ignored function.

title: Autommated multicollinearity reduction — mc_auto
code: mc_auto(   data = NULL,   predictors = NULL,   preference.order = NULL,   max.cor = 0.75,   max.vif = 5,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Autommated multicollinearity reduction — mc_auto
text: data (required; data.frame tibble) data frame, tibble, sf. Default: NULL. predictors (optional; character vector) Character vector names predictive variables. Every element vector must column names data. NULL, columns data except response used. Default: NULL preference.order (optional, character vector) Character vector indicating preference order protect variables elimination.  Predictors included argument ranked VIFs. Default: NULL. max.cor (optional; numeric) Numeric 0 1. Maximum Pearson correlation pair selected variables. Higher values return larger number predictors higher multicollinearity. Default: 0.75 max.vif (optional, numeric) Numeric recommended values 2.5 10 defining maximum VIF allowed output dataset. Higher VIF thresholds result higher number selected variables. Default: 5. verbose (optional, logical) Logical. TRUE, describes function operations user. Default: TRUE

title: Autommated multicollinearity reduction — mc_auto
text: Character vector names uncorrelated predictors.

title: Autommated multicollinearity reduction — mc_auto
code: if(interactive()){  data(   ecoregions,   ecoregions_continuous_response,   ecoregions_all_predictors )  #unsupervised multicollinearity reduction #------------------------------------------------ selected.predictors <- mc_auto(   data = ecoregions,   predictors = ecoregions_all_predictors,   max.cor = 0.75,   max.vif = 5   )   #supervised multicollinearity reduction #------------------------------------------------ #1. Notice that "fragmentation_ca" is selected #even though it has the maximum VIF in the dataset #2. "climate_bio12_average" is excluded from the result #because it's highly correlated to "climate_bio1_average" selected.predictors <- mc_auto(   data = ecoregions,   predictors = ecoregions_predictors,   preference.order = c(     "fragmentation_ca",     "climate_bio1_average",     "climate_bio12_average"   ),   max.cor = 0.75,   max.vif = 5 )  }

what: Automated multicollinearity reduction via pairwise Pearson correlation — mc_auto_cor
title: Automated multicollinearity reduction via pairwise Pearson correlation — mc_auto_cor
text: Iterative reduction multicollinearity via Pearson bivariate correlation. function mc_auto_cor() applies recursive algorithm remove variables Pearson correlation another variable higher given threshold (defined argument max.cor).  two variables correlated threshold, one highest sum R-squared variables removed. function mc_auto_cor() allows user define preference selection order via argument preference.order. preference.order "c("", "b"), correlated max.cor, variables data, sum R-squared variables "" higher sum "b", "b" removed anyway. argument preference.order allows user "protect" variables might interesting even required given analysis. preference.order provided, predictors ranked lower higher sum R-squared preodictors, removed one one maximum R-squared correlation matrix lower max.cor. Please note near-zero variance columns ignored function.

title: Automated multicollinearity reduction via pairwise Pearson correlation — mc_auto_cor
code: mc_auto_cor(   data = NULL,   predictors = NULL,   preference.order = NULL,   max.cor = 0.75,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Automated multicollinearity reduction via pairwise Pearson correlation — mc_auto_cor
text: data (required; data frame tibble) data frame predictors. Default: NULL. predictors (required; character vector) Character vector names predictive variables. Every element vector must column names data. NULL, columns data except response used. Default: NULL preference.order (optional; character vector) Character vector indicating user's order preference keep variables. Predictors included argument ranked sum correlation variables (variables higher sums receive lower ranks therefore lower preference order). Default: NULL. max.cor (optional; numeric) Numeric 0 1. Maximum Pearson correlation pair selected variables. Higher values return larger number predictors higher multicollinearity. Default: 0.75 verbose (optional, logical) Logical. TRUE, describes function operations user. Default: TRUE

title: Automated multicollinearity reduction via pairwise Pearson correlation — mc_auto_cor
text: Character vector names uncorrelated predictors.

title: Automated multicollinearity reduction via pairwise Pearson correlation — mc_auto_cor
code: if(interactive()){   #loading example data  data(   ecoregions,   ecoregions_predictors   )   #on a data frame  out <- mc_auto_cor(    data = ecoregions,    predictors = ecoregions_predictors  )   #getting the correlation matrix  out$cor   #getting the names of the selected variables  out$selected.variables   #getting the data frame of selected variables  out$selected.variables.df   #with preference order (fiver first in ecoregions_predictors)  out <- mc_auto_cor(    data = ecoregions,    predictors = ecoregions_predictors,    preference.order = ecoregions_predictors[1:5],  )   #with pipes  out <- mc_auto_cor(    data = ecoregions,    predictors = ecoregions_predictors  ) |>  mc_auto_vif()  }

what: Automated multicollinearity reduction via Variance Inflation Factor — mc_auto_vif
title: Automated multicollinearity reduction via Variance Inflation Factor — mc_auto_vif
text: Warning: input predictors pairwise correlation close 1 might create issues VIF computation. case, please apply mc_auto_cor() . Warning: near-zero variance columns ignored function. Variance Inflation Factor given variable y computed 1/(1-R2), R2 multiple R-squared multiple regression model fitted using y response remaining variables input data set predictors. equation can interpreted "rate perfect model's R-squared unexplained variance model". possible range VIF values (1, Inf]. VIF lower 10 suggest removing y data set reduce overall multicollinearity. recommended thresholds maximum VIF may vary depending source consulted, common values, 2.5, 5, 10. function mc_auto_vif() applies recursive algorithm remove variables VIF higher given threshold (defined argument max.vif). function allows user define preference selection order via argument preference.order. argument helps "protect" variables might interesting even required given analysis. Please, see examples understand better feature works.

title: Automated multicollinearity reduction via Variance Inflation Factor — mc_auto_vif
code: mc_auto_vif(   data = NULL,   predictors = NULL,   preference.order = NULL,   max.vif = 5,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Automated multicollinearity reduction via Variance Inflation Factor — mc_auto_vif
text: data (required; data.frame tibble) data frame, tibble, sf. Default: NULL. predictors (optional; character vector) Character vector names predictive variables. Every element vector must column names data. Default: NULL preference.order (optional, character vector) Character vector indicating preference order protect variables elimination.  Predictors included argument ranked VIFs. Default: NULL. max.vif (optional, numeric) Numeric recommended values 2.5 10 defining maximum VIF allowed output dataset. Higher VIF thresholds result higher number selected variables. Default: 5. verbose (optional, logical) Set FALSE silence messages. Default: TRUE

title: Automated multicollinearity reduction via Variance Inflation Factor — mc_auto_vif
text: Character vector names uncorrelated predictors.

title: Automated multicollinearity reduction via Variance Inflation Factor — mc_auto_vif
code: if(interactive()){  data(   ecoregions,   ecoregions_continuous_response,   ecoregions_predictors,   ecoregions_all_predictors )  #NUMERIC PREDICTORS ONLY ################################   #automatic VIF reduction with low max.vif #------------------------------- selected.predictors <- mc_auto_vif(   data = ecoregions,   predictors = ecoregions_predictors,   max.vif = 2 )  #check vif of the resulting dataset #variance inflation factor vif(data = ecoregions[, selected.predictors])  #a small number of predictors is selected length(selected.predictors)   #automatic VIF reduction with high max.vif #------------------------------- selected.predictors <- mc_auto_vif(   data = ecoregions,   predictors = ecoregions_predictors,   max.vif = 10 )  #a larger number of predictors is selected length(selected.predictors)   #supervised VIF reduction #------------------------------------------------ #1. Notice that "fragmentation_ca" is selected #even though it has the maximum VIF in the dataset #2. "climate_bio12_average" is excluded from the result #because it's highly correlated to "climate_bio1_average" selected.predictors <- mc_auto_vif(   data = ecoregions,   predictors = ecoregions_predictors,   preference.order = c(     "fragmentation_ca",     "climate_bio1_average",     "climate_bio12_average"   ) )   #using quantitative criteria as preference.order #----------------------------------------------- #computing univariate correlation between each predictor and the response preference.order <- apply(   X = ecoregions[, ecoregions_predictors],   MARGIN = 2,   FUN = function(x){     cor(       x = x,       y = ecoregions[, ecoregions_continuous_response]       )     }   )  #sorting from maximum to minimum and getting names only preference.order <- names(   sort(     preference.order,     decreasing = TRUE     )   )  #using it in mc_auto_vif as preference.order selected.predictors <- mc_auto_vif(   data = ecoregions,   predictors = ecoregions_predictors,   preference.order = preference.order )   #using mc_auto_vif and mc_auto_cor together #----------------------------------------------- mc_auto_cor.result <- mc_auto_cor(   data = ecoregions,   predictors = ecoregions_predictors,   preference.order = preference.order,   max.cor = 0.75 )  selected.predictors <- mc_auto_vif(   data = ecoregions,   predictors = mc_auto_cor.result,   preference.order = preference.order )  #NUMERIC AND CATEGORICAL PREDICTORS #-----------------------------------  #there are two categorial predictors in the dataset below class(ecoregions$dominant_landcover) class(ecoregions$primary_productivity)  #these variables are included in the vector ecoregions_all_predictors ecoregions_all_predictors[45:46]  #automatic VIF reduction using target-encoding for categorical predictors #--------------------------------------------------- #requires the name of the response to compute the target-encoding selected.predictors <- mc_auto_vif(   data = ecoregions,   predictors = ecoregions_all_predictors )  #both categorical predictors have been selected ecoregions_all_predictors[45:46] %in% selected.predictors   #applying target-encoding before vif #--------------------------------------------------- data.encoded <- fe_target_encoding(   data = ecoregions,   predictors = ecoregions_all_predictors,   methods = "mean",   replace = TRUE )  #now the function does not require the response's name selected.predictors <- mc_auto_vif(   data = data.encoded,   predictors = ecoregions_all_predictors )  #both categorical predictors have been selected again ecoregions_all_predictors[45:46] %in% selected.predictors   }

title: Variance Inflation Factor — mc_vif
text: Computes Variance Inflation Factor variables training data frame. Variance Inflation Factor given variable y computed 1/(1-R2), R2 multiple R-squared multiple regression model fitted using y response remaining variables input data set predictors. equation can interpreted "rate perfect model's R-squared unexplained variance model". possible range VIF values (1, Inf]. VIF lower 10 suggest removing y data set reduce overall multicollinearity. Please note near-zero variance columns ignored function. Use mc_auto_vif() remove .

title: Variance Inflation Factor — mc_vif
code: mc_vif(df = NULL, predictors = NULL, verbose = TRUE)

title: Variance Inflation Factor — mc_vif
text: df (required; data frame tibble) data frame predictors. Default: NULL. predictors (optional; character vector) Character vector names predictive variables. Every element vector must column names df. Default: NULL verbose (optional, logical) Set FALSE silence messages. Default: TRUE

title: Variance Inflation Factor — mc_vif
text: Data frame columns "variable" containing predictor name, "vif" containing variance inflation factor given variable.

title: Variance Inflation Factor — mc_vif
code: if(interactive()){  data(   ecoregions,   ecoregions_continuous_response,   ecoregions_all_predictors )  df <- mc_vif(       df = ecoregions,       predictors = ecoregions_all_predictors )  }

what: Target encode a categorical variable based on a numeric variable. — target_encode

text: function calculates mean numeric variable group defined categorical variable returns target-encoded values.

code: target_encode(numeric = NULL, character = NULL)

title: Target encode a categorical variable based on a numeric variable. — target_encode
text: numeric (required; numeric vector) numeric vector. character (required; character vector) character vector length 'numeric', representing categorical variable.

title: Target encode a categorical variable based on a numeric variable. — target_encode
text: numeric vector containing target-encoded values.

title: Target encode a categorical variable based on a numeric variable. — target_encode
code: if(interactive()){ data(ecoregions) encoded_values <- target_encode(   numeric = ecoregions$plant_richness,   character = ecoregions$dominant_landcover   ) }

title: Target-encoding methods — fe_target_encoding_mean
text: Methods apply target-encoding individual categorical variables. functions implemented : fe_target_encoding_mean(): group identified mean response group cases. White noise can added via noise argument. Columns encoded function identified suffix "__encoded_mean". noise used, amount noise also added suffix. fe_target_encoding_rank(): group identified rank mean response variable group cases. group lower mean receives rank 1. White noise can added via noise argument. Columns encoded function identified suffix "__encoded_rank". noise used, amount noise also added suffix. fe_target_encoding_rnorm(): case group receives value coming normal distribution mean standard deviation response cases group. argument sd.width multiplies standard deviation reduce spread obtained values. Columns encoded function identified suffix "__encoded_rnorm_sd.width_X", X amount sd.width used. fe_target_encoding_loo(): suffix "loo" stands "leave-one-". case group encoded average response cases group. olumns encoded function identified suffix "__encoded_loo".

title: Target-encoding methods — fe_target_encoding_mean
code: fe_target_encoding_mean(   df,   response,   categorical.variable.name,   noise = 0,   seed = 1,   replace = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE )  fe_target_encoding_rnorm(   df,   response,   categorical.variable.name,   sd.width = 0.1,   seed = 1,   replace = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE )  fe_target_encoding_rank(   df,   response,   categorical.variable.name,   noise = 0,   seed = 1,   replace = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE )  fe_target_encoding_loo(   df,   response,   categorical.variable.name,   replace = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE )  fe_target_encoding_noise(df, categorical.variable.name, noise = 0, seed = 1)

title: Target-encoding methods — fe_target_encoding_mean
text: df (required; data frame, tibble, sf) training data frame. Default: NULL response (required; character string) Name response. Must column name df. Default: NULL categorical.variable.name (required; character) Name categorical variable encode. noise (optional; numeric) Numeric noise values range 0-1. Default: 0. seed (optional; integer) Random seed facilitate reproducibility. Default: 1 replace (optional; logical) Advanced option changes behavior function. Use really know exactly need. TRUE, replaces categorical variable encoded version, returns input data frame replaced variables. verbose (optional; logical) TRUE, messages plots generated execution function displayed. Default: TRUE sd.width (optional; numeric) Numeric multiplicator standard deviation group categorical variable, range 0.01-1. Default: 0.1

title: Target-encoding methods — fe_target_encoding_mean
text: input data frame target-encoded variable.

title: Target-encoding methods — fe_target_encoding_mean
code: if(interactive()){  #target_encoding mean data(   ecoregions,   ecoregions_continuous_response,   ecoregions_all_predictors )  #the dataframe ecoregions contains a categorical variable named primary_productivity unique(ecoregions$primary_productivity)   #Group mean #########################################################  #transforming primary_productivity ecoregions <- fe_target_encoding_mean(   df = ecoregions,   response = ecoregions_continuous_response,   categorical.variable.name = "primary_productivity" )  #the encoded variable is named primary_productivity__encoded_mean  #plotting it against the response ggplot2::ggplot(data = ecoregions) +   ggplot2::aes(     x = plant_richness,     y = primary_productivity__encoded_mean,     color = primary_productivity   ) +   ggplot2::geom_point()   #Group rank #########################################################  #transforming primary_productivity ecoregions <- fe_target_encoding_rank(   df = ecoregions,   response = ecoregions_continuous_response,   categorical.variable.name = "primary_productivity" )  #the encoded variable is named primary_productivity__encoded_rank  #plotting it against the response ggplot2::ggplot(data = ecoregions) +   ggplot2::aes(     x = plant_richness,     y = primary_productivity__encoded_rank,     color = primary_productivity   ) +   ggplot2::geom_point()   #Leave-one-out ######################################################### #transforming primary_productivity ecoregions <- fe_target_encoding_loo(   df = ecoregions,   response = ecoregions_continuous_response,   categorical.variable.name = "primary_productivity" )  #the encoded variable is named primary_productivity__encoded_loo  #plotting it against the response ggplot2::ggplot(data = ecoregions) +   ggplot2::aes(     x = plant_richness,     y = primary_productivity__encoded_loo,     color = primary_productivity   ) +   ggplot2::geom_point()   #rnorm #########################################################  #transforming primary_productivity ecoregions <- fe_target_encoding_rnorm(   df = ecoregions,   response = ecoregions_continuous_response,   categorical.variable.name = "primary_productivity" )  #the encoded variable is named primary_productivity__encoded_rnorm_sd.width_0.1  #plotting it against the response ggplot2::ggplot(data = ecoregions) +   ggplot2::aes(     x = plant_richness,     y = primary_productivity__encoded_rnorm_sd.width_0.1,     color = primary_productivity   ) +   ggplot2::geom_point()   }
